content:
Hi Wayne (from LiveInHope)

Apologies for not replying sooner - I'm writing from Edinburgh, Scotland, so guess quite a time difference.

Could I just say, I really do appreciate Thunderbird and all the voluntary work that goes into it . . .

On your query as to who said they had a 'fix', I think it was here:

https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1855611#a9976491_29811

Somebody called Allesandro Castellani I think claimed it was fixed?

Thank you for the explanation that the entire code was re-written, so it's not just a case of putting the old back.

I still wonder if I'm missing something? I'm using a perfectly standard Dell 24" monitor and I like emails on the horizontal format.

On a typical email page, from the top, 1.5" are taken up with the headers, then 3.5" are taken up with the ten Message List Pane entries. Then, on the actual email below, 2.25" are taken up with that header, leaving just 4.25" below for the actual email content! I can't see any way to change that, but surely you would agree that 4.25" of email on a screen 11.5" deep is just useless!

Given the scores of people who have complained (many listed on your posts on the above link), I just cannot understand why fixing this has not been a priority.)

Thanks for your efforts - i hope you manage to get something done.

(NB shhowes comments are of no use to me - I'm not a computer programmer.)
creator: rwadallas

content:
I will try to assist here. - For many/most email clients, there is the option available to set the option to either include original correspondence or to ignore original correspondence. That option appears to have been set for those people replying to you, as Thunderbird has no facility to remove portions of messages.

- Regarding spam, this is a teaching process, wherein you can click messages that are flagged as spam and click 'not spam' and return to desired folder. It is generally advised to do this periodically for both good and spam messsages to help Thunderbird 'learn' how to manage your email. This article provides more information: 

https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/thunderbird-and-junk-spam-messages
creator: davidsk

content:
I am not a specialist at network problems, but the error message sent me searching for answers, as it looked like there was a problem with your email domain. I found the following text on a Microsoft support site, responding the the same issue from a user (error smtp 450 4.7.1).

"Error 450 4.7.1 indicates that the Exchange server is performing the reverse lookups to identify the address from where you are sending the email. Example: Suppose you want to send an email from example@domain.com, as you send the emails, your system is stamped with the IP address of your system. Now, when the server receives the email, it verifies first whether the email is sent through the same domain by verifying its IP address. It checks whether the IP address is pointing to the same domain, i.e. example@domain.com. If the server was not able to detect the sender of email or is not able to identify the hostname, then Error code 450 4.7.1 Client host rejected: cannot find your reverse hostname is encountered.

"We strongly advise contacting your recipient's email provider to check the configuration of Mail server and verify whether domain records of DNS has been setup properly or not.

"If your IP address is blacklisted by the server, find out the main cause of blocking. An IP address is generally marked as blacklisted when they are sending spam link or content. Request the server to remove your IP address from the blacklist.

Errors of the type if surfaced recently, possibly as email hosts are using tighter security checks. Sometimes, the error message focuses on DKIM and SPF settings within the email host server. To summarize, this problem needs to be fixed by your email host provider, unless your email domain is self-hosted, in which it may be your responsibility. However, my experience is that email host tech support personnel should be able to address this for you.
creator: davidsk

content:
That happens when Thunderbird detects an abnormality in a profile and starts anew . If you have a complete backup, my suggestion is to: - exit thunderbird - copy the backup profile to overlay one with same name - restart thunderbird - click help>troubleshootinginformation, scroll down to 'profile folders' and click 'about:profiles and select to use that profile.

If your backup was the Thunderbird folder and not just the profile folder, then all you need to do is copy the thunderbird folder to overlay the existing thunderbird folder when Thunderbird is not running.

content:
Hi there, it sounds like you're hitting a limitation of the default permissions given to the flatpak. Because flatpaks (and snaps) are containerized applications, they don't have access to all the same locations that a typical deb package would have, unless that permission is granted either at build time or by you at runtime.

In Pop_OS and it's Cosmic desktop environment, you can see some high level of the permissions given to each flatpak in the Settings > Applications > Thunderbird. You will notice that there's not much you can do here. If you want a more full featured way of tweaking the permissions of your flatpaks, I recommend installing flatseal - a tool devised to do just that.

`flatpak install flathub com.github.tchx84.Flatseal`

Then you run flatseal and go to Thunderbird and scroll down to the Filesystem section. Here you can try granting the flatpak the permission to access other directories like home or even all directories on the host. Then restart Thunderbird and hopefully this solves your problem.
creator: linuxflower

content:
Matt's reply led me to try to learn enough about github to install flatseal, but Heather's instructions seemed plain enough to try outright.

I ran the automated Flatseal installation to completion, installing for user rather than system.

I closed Thunderbird, opened Flatseal, and gave Thunderbird access to 'All user files'; closed and reopened Flatseal to make sure the setting was permanent. Closed Flatseal. Looked good, I thought.

But when I re-opened Thunderbird via the launcher, it sent me to a configuration window for setting up a new account. With little choice, I set it up. There were NO local folders, which is where all my emails (several years worth) reside.

In the file browser, I found that a new $HOME/.thunderbird directory had been created with 2 new profiles primary 'default-release' and secondary 'default'.

A copy of this same 'default release' had also appeared in the original $HOME/var/app/org.mozilla.Thunderbird/cache/thunderbird profile directory, alongside the original default-default profile. And that profile, formerly with all my archived emails, was reduced to 725 MB, down from 16.3 GB. (I have a copy from last Wednesday).

It seems that Running Flatseal and changing file access caused a reinstallation of Thunderbird that wiped out on-disk mail. Can anyone recommend the best way to restore the original profile from this mess?

Thanks again.

content:
This must be done on an account by account basis. - select table view - the icon just to right of 'quick filter' button above message list pane - select a message folder and apply all desired attributes - View>sort by from menu bar (if not shown, click alt key) - click the icon at right side of column display in message list pane - select the entry near bottom 'Apply current view to...' - highlight 'folder and children' - move mouse left to see account name and move left again to display all account folders. Now CLICK. - a small menu will appear to confirm setting all folders within that account.

I did a simple (okay, crude) video at https://davidkirk.org/SettingDefaultFolderView.mp4

content:
You statement that is works in outlook leaves me to think the issue may well be external to Thunderbird. Outlook does not use connection encryption be default for most mail accounts. Thunderbird does, even if the provider does not necessarily recommend it.

Antivirus product on the whole use self signed certificates to hack encrypted connections for scan mail. As these certificates are self signed they are not in the global chain of trust on which the whole SSL/TLS setup is based, so Thunderbird refuses them. Unfortunately this is also an area where error do not necessarily bubble up to the user (it is shared code with Firefox and the Thunderbird folk have little of no experience here, so we depend on Mozilla doing the right thing with bugs. Not always successfully.) The result is the user is not always notified of the rejection.

So disable scanning of encrypted traffic and email in your antivirus product and see if that improves the outcome. Or boot your operating system into safe mode with networking for the account installation process.
creator: MattAuSupport
